channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Rural areas have a message for Newsom: One size doesn't fit all in reopening California
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: California's rural areas are in revolt against Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide coronavirus rules, which make little sense in burgs such as Bieber.
item.content:encoded: California's rural areas are in revolt against Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide coronavirus rules, which make little sense in burgs such as Bieber.

media:content.media:description: State Sen. Jim Nielsen, R-Tehama, left discusses the impact the coronavirus is having on rural residents and businesses during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, April 28, 2020. Representatives of six north state counties are calling on Gov. Gavin Newsom to allow them to exercise local authority to implement a careful and phased reopening of the local economies. Nielsen was accompanied by Yuba City restaurant owners Sharlene Katz, of the Dancing Tomato Caffe, second from left and Chris and Sandee Drown of the Happy Viking restaurant. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Navy took lessons from coronavirus outbreaks on three other ships to act quickly aboard Kidd
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dyer
item.description: The 330-person crew aboard the guided-missile destroyer Kidd might be infected with more coronavirus cases if the Navy didn't act so quickly, according to a vice admiral in charge of the Navy's surface force.
item.content:encoded: The 330-person crew aboard the guided-missile destroyer Kidd might be infected with more coronavirus cases if the Navy didn't act so quickly, according to a vice admiral in charge of the Navy's surface force.

media:content.media:description: SAN DIEGO (April 28, 2020) – Hospital Corpsman 2nd Class Shane Miller, left, and Hospital Corpsman 2nd Class Austin Kelly, both assigned to Fleet Surgical Team 9, draw blood from a Sailor assigned to the guided-missile destroyer USS Kidd (DDG 100) after its arrival in San Diego April 28 as part of the Navy's response to the COVID-19 outbreak on board the ship. (U.S. Navy photo by Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Alex Corona/ Released)
media:content.media:credit: Petty Officer 2nd Class Alex Corona/U.S. Navy

item.title: Some California businesses reopen in defiance of coronavirus stay-at-home orders
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: From the high desert to the beach enclaves of Orange County, a growing number of California businesses deemed nonessential are choosing to reopen in defiance of orders from local and state authorities.
item.content:encoded: From the high desert to the beach enclaves of Orange County, a growing number of California businesses deemed nonessential are choosing to reopen in defiance of orders from local and state authorities.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2020. Cops and protesters find a shady spot along Pacific Coast Highway in Laguna Beach on Saturday, May 2, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Barbara News-Press owner compares COVID restrictions to Nazi Germany; editor exits
item.dc:creator: Deborah Netburn
item.description: The Santa Barbara News-Press lost its editor in chief this weekend after the newspaper published an editorial by owner and co-publisher Wendy McCaw that accused Democratic lawmakers of using the coronavirus for their own political agenda and compared stay-at-home orders to Nazi Germany.

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases top 25,000, with more than 1,200 deaths
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials have reported 781 new cases of the coronavirus and 21 additional related deaths.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials have reported 781 new cases of the coronavirus and 21 additional related deaths.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: COVID-19 finally came. Armed with a plan, Mariposa County was waiting to fight back
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: When this rural California county got its first coronavirus case last week, officials were ready with a plan they had hatched early on in the outbreak.
item.content:encoded: When this rural California county got its first coronavirus case last week, officials were ready with a plan they had hatched early on in the outbreak.

media:content.media:description: MARIPOSA, CA - APRIL 30, 2020 - - Matthew Matthiessen, CEO of John C. Fremont Hospital, has his temperature read while being screened by EMT Doug Michael in Mariposa on April 30, 2020. All employees at the hospital have to be screened for symptom of COVID-19 and are asked questions if they have any symptoms from the virus before they are allowed to go to work. Mariposa County is one of five California counties that as of April 28 only had one reported coronavirus case, despite the fact all the surroundings have. More than 47,000 Californians have tested positive for the novel coronavirus but in Mariposa County, Tuesday's result was the first. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: In the coronavirus shutdown, people turn to GoFundMe to ask strangers for the basics: money for food and rent to survive

media:content.media:description: ALHAMBRA, CA-MAY 1, 2020: Roberta Wall, 63, a singing waitress at Micelli's Italian restaurant on Cahuenga Blvd in Universal City, is photographed at her home in Alhambra. Wall, who has worked there since 1986 has been out of work since March 15, when the restaurant stopped having dine in customers due to the coronavirus outbreak. She posted a GoFundMe asking for help but didn't tell anyone she knew because she figured they needed help as much as she did so she got no donations. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fear, uncertainty, exhaustion: One doctor's shift in the UCLA emergency room
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: An ER doctor promises a COVID-19 patient tests, a bed, oxygen and wishes she could do more.
item.content:encoded: An ER doctor promises a COVID-19 patient tests, a bed, oxygen and wishes she could do more.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 06: Dr. Lisa Dabby, 41, an emergency room physician with UCLA Medical Center in Santa Monica is assisted by Sr. emergency trauma technician Jorge Velasco in the donning of a PAPR (powered air-purifying respirator) in the emergency room where they are on the front line of the coronavirus COVID-19 outbreak. During a typical 10-hour shift, she treats appendicitis, overdoses, skateboard accidents, arrhythmia, the usual off-the-street accidents, illnesses and conditions that flare up without notice. With more than 10 years at the hospital, she knows what to expect and how to treat it, but the coronavirus has changed that. She treats about 20 patients a day who arrive with coughs, fevers, shortness of breath and the fear and uncertainty that this pandemic has brought.UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Will Orange County enforce Newsom beach closure? Officials vow a fight
item.dc:creator: Anh Do, Hannah Fry, Richard Winton
item.description: Huntington Beach and Dana Point have voted to seek injunctions, and the Orange County sheriff has said he doesn't plan to arrest beachgoers.
item.content:encoded: Huntington Beach and Dana Point have voted to seek injunctions, and the Orange County sheriff has said he doesn't plan to arrest beachgoers.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 2020: Kids do flips off the lifeguard tower while others relax on the sand on the last day of open beaches in Huntington Beach after Gov. Newsom announced the "hard close" of all Orange County state and local beaches Thursday, April 30, 2020. Newsom's retaliation came after thousands of Californians flocked to the shoreline there over the weekend in defiance of a statewide stay-at-home order enacted to stem the spread of the coronavirus. "When you contact the police chiefs to enforce your will as a leader-in my book you establish a police state" said Huntington Beach resident Pete Hamborg. "It's a moment that Gavin Newsom is taking away from us and are the very moments that empower us to deal with this crisis on a day-to-day basis." "I think the beach, which belongs to all Californians, is critical to our emotional health and well-being." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 17, 2020 - Janet Martinez, left, with the Binational Front of Indigenous Organizations (FIOB), talks with Luis Gabriel, from Oaxaca, Mexico, after giving him a relief check in Los Angeles on April 17, 2020. Gabriel is one of many indigenous people from Mexico and Guatemala who have lost employment due to the coronavirus. The Binational Front of Indigenous Organizations was given a $10,000 grant and an additional $5,000 donation to help indigenous people from Mexico and Guatemala, who are out of work in Los Angeles. Workers with the FIOB have been helping those who have lost their jobs by providing some funding and producing educational videos in indigenous languages. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

Gavin Newsom speaks during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. A coalition of marijuana companies, churches and advocacy groups is asking Newsom for a temporary cut in the state's hefty pot taxes. The group that includes the California State Conference of the NAACP, Los Angeles Metropolitan Churches and the industry group Southern California Coalition warned in a letter to the governor that the coronavirus crisis and a crashing economy will take an especially heavy toll on businesses run by minorities who were disproportionately targeted during the decades-long drug war. media:content.media:description: Real estate heir Robert Durst sits during his murder trial at the Airport Branch Courthouse in Los Angeles on Thursday, March 5, 2020. After a Hollywood film about him, an HBO documentary full of seemingly damning statements, and decades of suspicion, Durst is now on trial for murder. In opening statements Wednesday, prosecutors will argue Durst killed his close friend Susan Berman before New York police could interview her about the 1982 disappearance of Durst's wife. (Robyn Beck/AFP via AP, Pool)

After 15 minutes the officers let them stay. California Governor Gavin Newsome's closed Orange County beaches to slow the spread of the coronavirus. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inside this scrappy Silver Lake mask emporium
item.dc:creator: Mel Melcon
item.description: Laura Howe repurposed fabric from her Matrushka Construction boutique to make masks for the coronavirus outbreak. She's sold 8,000.
item.content:encoded: Laura Howe repurposed fabric from her Matrushka Construction boutique to make masks for the coronavirus outbreak. She's sold 8,000.

media:content.media:description: SILVER LAKE, CA-APRIL 22, 2020: Laura Howe, owner and designer at Matrushka Construction, a women's boutique in Silver Lake, works with telephone themed fabric, that is being used to make masks. After running out of scraps from fabric used to make dresses, she is now buying fabric, like this one at the garment district in downtown Los Angeles, specifically to be used for making masks. At right is her dog Baby, an Italian Mastiff. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Amid a puzzling pandemic, they started posting riddles outside. Here's what came next
item.dc:creator: Stuart Leavenworth
item.description: In Mar Vista, a family started posting riddles on their front lawn each day. Soon, the neighborhood was riddled with riddles, creating new ways for neighbors to connect.
item.content:encoded: In Mar Vista, a family started posting riddles on their front lawn each day. Soon, the neighborhood was riddled with riddles, creating new ways for neighbors to connect.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 24: Jay and Kate Larsen with their two children Reid, 6, and River, 4, started posting a hand-painted riddle on the front lawn each day to brighten up the lives of Mar Vista neighbors after the coronavirus lockdown started. It has become a phenom in the neighborhood, with others using their front yards for riddles, games, and whimsical displays. The Larsons then helped organize a treasure hunt for kids and families creating closer neighborhood bonds, even at a safe distance. Mar VIsta on Friday, April 24, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Face masks thrown on freeway cause traffic jam in California
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: The California Highway Patrol says someone who tossed hundreds of medical masks onto a freeway sparked a mini-traffic jam in Union City.
item.content:encoded: The California Highway Patrol says someone who tossed hundreds of medical masks onto a freeway sparked a mini-traffic jam in Union City.

media:content.media:description: One of the spilled masks is visible on the shoulder of southbound Interstate 880 in Union City, Calif., Wednesday, April 29, 2020. In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, the freeway suffered a mini-traffic jam when someone tossed hundreds of face masks onto the road and some motorists stopped to grab them, the California Highway Patrol reported. At around 1:30 p.m., CHP officers received a report that a white truck had stopped on Interstate 880 in Union City and someone tossed out boxes of medical masks, the CHP reported. (Dai Sugano/Bay Area News Group via AP)
